Thanks to Marcus Sundberg for providing common cylinder capacities in metric.

In order to store a cylinder size, you must choose a name, set the fill pressure, and specify how big the cylinder is. Size can be set in two ways:


If you know the internal volume of the cylinder, enter that. Cylinder manufacturers usually have this number in their specifications, and divers outside of the U.S. tend to think of their cylinder size this way anyway. If you are using this size for gas blending, you will get the most accurate results by setting this number.


Divers in the U.S. and surrounding areas consider cylinder size in terms of capacity at service pressure, e.g. an Aluminum 80 holds 80 cubic feet of gas. If you know only this number, you can enter it in as the Capacity and the internal volume will be computed. This number is not as accurate, though, for describing how much gas the cylinder really holds.


If you wish to use manifolded doubles, enter the total combined size of the two tanks as the "cylinder" size.


You can switch between imperial and metric for all cylinders by pressing the Menu button on the list screen. The units button on the edit screen lets you switch back and forth temporarily, but it will not save for next time.
